name.text: Determining Continuity of a Piecewise Function

questiontext.text:
Determine if the following function is continuous at \(x=4\) and \(x=6\):

\[ f(x) = \begin{cases} {@f1@} & x\leq 6 \\ {@f2@} & x > 6  \end{cases} \]

State "yes" or "no" for each case:

At \(x=4\): [[input:ans1]] 

At \(x=6\): [[input:ans2]] 

[[validation:ans1]]

[[validation:ans2]]

[[feedback:prt1]]

[[feedback:prt2]]

generalfeedback.text:
Worked Solution

At \(x=4\), the function is \({@f1@}\), which is itself continuous. Therefore, \(f(x)\) is continuous at \(x=4\).

To the left of \(x = 6\), the function is {@f1@}, therefore, \( \displaystyle \lim_{x\rightarrow 6^-} f(x) = {@aa@} \cdot 6 = {@aa*6@}\).

To the right of \(x = 6\), the function is {@f2@}, therefore, \( \displaystyle \lim_{x\rightarrow 6^+} f(x) = {@bb@} \cdot 6 {@sig@} {@abs(cc)@} = {@bb*6+cc@}\).

Therefore, \(f(x)\) is not continuous at \(x=6\).

prtcorrect.text: Correct answer, well done.

prtpartiallycorrect.text: Your answer is partially correct.

prtincorrect.text: Incorrect answer.
